resources.string: Touch to continue whit this savegame

"Muñatones Castle is located in Muskiz, Bizkaia. Somorrostro is a town in the valley, formed by the Barbadun river. It has around 7,500 inhabitants and the municipality is located in a protected natural space. We will find this castle we are talking about in front of the Petronor company refinery. Although it is called a castle, it is a tower house. It should be noted that it is not just any tower, but that of Lope García de Salazar, One of the most prominent personalities of the Middle Ages in Bizkaia. It was built in 1339, at the end of the aforementioned period. The current castle of Muñatones was built and destroyed over the centuries. with all kinds of wins and losses. Today, castle of Muñatones It is the only castle in Bizkaia that has preserved most of the characteristics of its time. "
You have to wait for the teacher to finish giving the explanation
Where have we entered the route?
What have we seen in the route?
Where can we take a bath?

St Juan is known as the shortest day of the year, although in fact actual date is June 21st. When is the summer solstice celebrated? The adaptation made by Christianism explains that it does not coincide with the summer solstice. Tonight with San Joan will be celebrated, fire burns everything, fire is desired and summer will be welcomed. In addition to being a magical day, it can also ward off bad spirits or what happened breaking with bad things. In the past, these fires were lit to give more power to the sun and thus extend the light. In the past, it was celebrated as a pagan festival, as the sun was considered a god. With the advent of Christianity, the celebration changed, but it has never lost its essence. Nowadays, tradition and rituals are mixed, and everyone celebrates as they want, dancing around the fire, jumping over it, enjoying the night. The origin of this date is the day of the birth of Saint John the Baptist, as his father Zacharias ordered a fire to be lit to announce the birth of his son. In Muskizen, the descent of the torches, which starts at the station at 22:30, is of great importance. Then, around 11:30 p.m., the fireworks start, followed by a verbena. That night, people who come to Muskize light torches up to the old warehouse of Petronor, together with the whistlers, and then throw the torches into the bonfire of San Jorge.
Complete the games to get badges!
The Romanesque bridge of El Pobal leads to the El Pobal ironworks, over the Barbadun river. It was built in the XIII. century, and Muskiz was the oldest bridge in the city.

The Barbadun River ran through the center of Muskiz, so they had to build a bridge to be able to move around the town without any problem. Thanks to this, people could travel from Galdames and Sopuerta to Muskiz. This bridge was necessary due to demographic problems.

The bridge is made of stone. It had two arched eyes, but today it only has one, as the other sank in the Carlist Wars, and today a concrete walkway has been built in its place. It is approximately two meters wide and has no protective walls. To prevent the bridge from falling down, a large pillar was built. It is still passable today, but it has not been used for a long time.
In what century was the Romanesque bridge of Pobal built?
What was this bridge built for?
What is the bridge made of?
For animals to pass from one side to the other
So that people from Galdames and Sopuerta can pass to Muskiz

La Arena beach located between the Vizcayan municipalities of Zierbena and Muskiz, Basque Country (Spain), is a beach with dark sand, next to the mouth of the Barbadún river, next to the towns of La Arena (Ciérvana) and Pobeña ( Muskiz).
The Romanesque bridge of El Pobal leads to the El Pobal ironworks, over the Barbadun river. XIII. It was built in the century and was the oldest bridge in the city of Muskiz.

El Pobal Burdinola antzinako fabrika hidrauliko bat da, non burdin minerala lantzen zen mota guztietako tresnak egiteko, batez ere etxeko erabilerarako.Barbadún ibaiaren ondoan eraiki zen XVI.mendearen hasieran.
Part of the beach is included in the protected natural area of the Barbadun estuary.
The greenway of Itsaslur, popularly known as the Itsaslur walk, unites the urban centers of Pobeña and Kobaron creating one of the most beautiful walks in Bizkaia.

The hermitage of Nuestra Señora del Socorro was built in 1768 and is located near the mouth of the Barbadun River. They call it Nuestra Señora del Socorro because they used it when there was danger to ask for help, which made it one of the favorites of the sailors of Pobeña, who were always at sea when they went fishing. Therefore, before starting to fish, the boats stopped there, went up to ask for protection and checked the state of the sea, to decide whether it was convenient to embark or not.
The time has come to create a new room so your pupils can join in!

The Feast of San Juan, also called the eve of San Juan or the Night of San Juan, is the eve of the celebration prior to the Christian festival of the birth of Saint John the Baptist on June 24. Some link the festival or some of its celebrations to rites of pagan origin prior to or alien to Christianity. The making of bonfires is usually a common element.

The watchtowers and signaling posts were very simple structures, and in particular that of Pobeña, they were created between the 16th century. and XVIII. In addition to meeting the needs of the mussels, this viewpoint was used as a fishing area to manage commercial traffic with iron ore from the Somorrostro mines and iron from the forges on the Barbadún River, with the help of small boats that passed by.

We are a group of UPV Teaching students. Together with a group of students from the CIFP Txurdinaga we have carried out an application so that the children of primary school in Muskiz can learn about playing.

In this game you must answer certain questions correctly, to reach the end . Good luck!
In this game you must answer correctly if the sea is calm or on the contrary, it is agitated . Good luck!

The night of San Juan is known as the shortest night of the year, although the truth is that the current date is June 21, when the summer solstice is celebrated. The adaptation of Christianity explains that it does not correspond to the summer solstice. Tonight is celebrated with the Houses of San Juan, the fire burns everything, the fire is desired and the summer will be welcomed. In addition to being a magical day, drive away evil spirits or break with bad things that have happened.

In the past, these fires were lit with the intention of giving more strength to the sun and thus extending the light. Formerly it was celebrated as a pagan festival, since the sun was considered a god. With the arrival of Christianity, the celebration changed, but it has never lost its essence. Today, tradition and rituals are mixed, and everyone celebrates it as they want, dancing around the fire, jumping over it, enjoying the night.
The origin of this date is the day of the birth of Saint John the Baptist, as his father Zacharias ordered a fire to be lit to announce the birth of his son.
